docs.lead_paragraph: MEASURING the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has become a relentless exercise among economists, politicians, journalists, historians and everyday people. In its simplest terms, taking numeric stock of damages and changes is the necessary stuff of recovery --the basis for making decisions on the allocation of funds, the adjustment of interest rates, or at a more mundane level, whether to take that holiday trip to the Big Apple. But the counting ritual is also therapeutic -- a means for getting a handle on events that may still feel wildly out of control. It wasn't until I saw the second jetliner smash into the second tower that it really dawned on me: Terrorists were intent on destroying our society and our economy, wrote Richard Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley, in an essay for the National Association of Business Economics.

headline.main: Word for Word/Weights and Measures; In the Aftermath of Terror, Grab a Calculator and Tally Forth

docs.abstract: Impact of Sept 11 terrorist attacks is being measured and counted in various ways, from sales of television sets, airline industry layoffs, crime to soaring number of prescriptions for antidepressant and antianxiety drugs; photos; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, in New York, one of Dr. Thomas Diflo's patients on a long waiting list for a kidney transplant showed up with a new problem: she no longer needed a kidney, but suddenly needed after-transplant care. ''She had just returned from a trip to China and, to my surprise, had undergone a transplant while she was there,'' said Dr. Diflo, of New York University Medical Center, where he is director of kidney transplants.

headline.main: Quandary in U.S. Over Use of Organs Of Chinese Inmates

docs.abstract: Kidneys, livers, corneas and other body parts from executed Chinese prisoners are being transplanted into American citizens or permanent residents who would otherwise have to wait years for organs; Dr Thomas Diflo cites Chinese-American patient who returned from China with new kidney; many such patients return to US for follow-up care, often paid for by Medicaid or other government programs; transplants in China, which doctors in both countries say are increasing, pose ethical dilemma; photos; executed prisoners are China's primary source of transplantable organs, although few of condemned, if any, give consent; US bill would bar US entry to Chinese doctors seeking transplant training (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hockey equipment spills off the side porch of the stately but welcoming brick house in Pelham Manor, N.Y. There are a football by the kitchen door, soccer cleats in the hallway and a basketball migrating about. In the mudroom, near the perpetually running washer and dryer, a meticulous carpenter has built cubicles to control the chaos. Danny's cleats. Casey's shin guards. Peter's gloves and pads. Patrick's hard hat -- the bright yellow kind grieving families are given when they visit ground zero. On the wall across from the cubbies is a wooden cabinet filled with shelves. This carpenter was not so meticulous. The shelves are slightly crooked, the cabinet itself is somewhat lopsided and the paint job is less than perfect. ''Joe built that,'' Nancy Shea says as she plucks clothes from the floor and plunks them in the wash. Joe. Husband to Nancy and father to Danny, Casey, Peter and Patrick. Joe, who called home that hellish morning to say he was O.K. and then died on the 105th floor. ''I always told him it was a good thing he didn't make his living as a carpenter,'' Nancy says with a watery smile. ''Can you imagine?'' she says, running her hands along the shelves her husband built. ''My whole life would have looked like this.''
docs.abstract: Article describes sorrow, and newly-developed coping skills, of families of Daniel and Joseph Shea, brothers who worked at Cantor Fitzgerald and who died on Sept 11; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York Republicans appear headed toward a showdown with the Bush administration and Republican leaders in the House, demanding billions of dollars in additional federal aid to help New York rebuild from the terrorist attack. In a rare alliance, New York Republicans are siding with their Democratic colleagues in the House, potentially provoking a confrontation that could force Republican leaders on the Hill and the Bush administration to support added spending for New York.

headline.main: Upstate Republicans in House Join Democrats in Fight for More Money for New York

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of employees are being forced to drop their health plans and choose a different one this month as companies across the country sharply reduce their rosters of H.M.O.'s and other managed care insurers. Some employees will have to change doctors as well, if their physicians are not on the roster of the new health plan. Everyone who makes the switch will have to deal with a new set of customer service representatives and often different rules and out-of-pocket payments.

headline.main: Fewer Choices For Workers On Benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats pushed their economic recovery plan through the Senate Finance Committee tonight, setting out their negotiating position on an issue that has left the two parties bitterly divided and at risk of deadlock even as unemployment surges and business activity slows. The $66.4 billion plan, which includes an expansion of programs to help the unemployed, a tax rebate for low-income people and tax breaks for some businesses, was approved by the committee on a vote of 11 to 10. The swing vote came from Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, whose departure from the Republican Party earlier this year to become an independent threw control of the Senate to the Democrats.

headline.main: Democrats' Recovery Plan Moves Forward in Senate

docs.abstract: Democrats push economic recovery plan through Senate Finance Committee, setting out negotiating position on issue that has left both parties bitterly divided and at risk of deadlock even as unemployment surges and business activity slows; $66.4 billion plan--which includes expansion of programs to help unemployed, tax-rebate for low-income people and tax breaks for some businesses--was approved 11-10 by committee on swing vote from Sen James M Jeffords, whose departure from Republican Party earlier in year to become independent threw control of Senate to Democrats; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna reported today that it had a loss of $54.4 million in the third quarter, reflecting higher medical costs. For the three months ended Sept. 30, Aetna lost 38 cents a share, compared with a profit of $59.6 million, or $1.24 a share, in the period a year earlier. Excluding nonoperating items, Aetna lost $49.3 million, or 34 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call were expecting a loss of 55 cents a share.

headline.main: Aetna Reports Loss for Third Quarter

docs.abstract: Aetna reports loss of $54.4 million in third quarter ended Sept 30, compared with profit of $59.6 million year earlier; revenue fell 8 percent, to $6.19 billion from $6.74 billion; chairman-chief executive John W Rowe comments (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Governor-elect James E. McGreevey exulted today in his victory over Bret D. Schundler and thanked voters for their support at his first post-election news conference. But he also issued a stark warning about the tough fiscal situation that he and the newly elected state legislators will face when they take office. ''Santa isn't coming to the State Legislature with Christmas tree lists this year,'' he said. ''We need to cut back. We need to be fiscally responsible. We need to live within our means.''

headline.main: McGreevey Warns of Tough Fiscal Future in New Jersey

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov-elect James McGreevey thanks voters but also issues stark warning about tough fiscal situation he and Legislature face; photos; deflects questions about transition plans and cabinet; reports his pregnant wife, Dina, is doing well in hospital; fields barrage of questions about state's looming budget deficit, repeats that he will not raise taxes and promises thorough review of state spending; tables on voter decisions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The real estate developer who holds the World Trade Center lease fired back at one of the complex's biggest insurers yesterday, filing a lawsuit demanding that the insurer promptly pay its share of the coverage -- even while litigation continues to determine how much the insurers are liable for. A larger dispute turns on the question of whether the attacks on the twin towers were a single event covered for $3.6 billion, as the insurer asserts, or two events representing a claim of $7.2 million.

headline.main: Trade Center Leaseholder Sues a Big Reinsurer
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FINE PRINT

docs.abstract: Real estate developer Larry A Silversten, who holds World Trade Center lease, files federal lawsuit demanding that Swiss Re insurance company promptly pay its share of coverage, even while litigation continues, so that Silverstein can make his payments to mortgage holder and Port Authority, which owns property; dispute continues as to whether attacks on twin towers were single event covered for $3.6 billion or two events representing claim of $7.2 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress headed today toward a major confrontation with President Bush over tax and spending policy, vowing to defy his threat to veto legislation that provides additional money to counter terrorism in the United States. The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, sided with the president, who told lawmakers on Tuesday that they should wait until next year to review whether more money was needed beyond the $40 billion Congress had already provided. The leaders put pressure on their colleagues, winning support from top Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee who had favored added spending.

headline.main: Spending War With White House Focuses on Countering Terrorism

docs.abstract: Democrats in Congress vow to defy Pres Bush's threat to veto legislation to counter terrorism that exceeds $40 billion that was approved by both houses of Congress on Sept 14, three days after World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks and before outbreak of anthrax threats and other security concerns; Democrats seek to add $10 billion to $20 billion--to hire agents at FBI, Customs Service and Border Patrol, to upgrade public health system, to purchase smallpox vaccine and antibiotics, and to pay for new food safety and airport security measures; Bush's veto threat is risky, because many Republican lawmakers would like to vote for more money for popular antiterrorism efforts; photo (M)
